title: COMP/STAT112 Notebook
text:
Introduction
This is my online notebook for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.

title: 1  Activity 01- Data Viz
text:
# Load the package
library(tidyverse)

# Import data
hikes <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/high_peaks.csv")


head(hikes)

             peak elevation difficulty ascent length time    rating
1     Mt. Marcy        5344          5   3166   14.8 10.0  moderate
2 Algonquin Peak       5114          5   2936    9.6  9.0  moderate
3   Mt. Haystack       4960          7   3570   17.8 12.0 difficult
4   Mt. Skylight       4926          7   4265   17.9 15.0 difficult
5 Whiteface Mtn.       4867          4   2535   10.4  8.5      easy
6       Dix Mtn.       4857          5   2800   13.2 10.0  moderate


What features would we like a visualization of the categorical difficulty rating variable to capture? - A bar chart would be good for a categorical variable such as difficulty.
What about a visualization of the quantitative elevation variable? - A histogram would be good for elevation variable.

# Use the ggplot function
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating))







# Adding geom_bar() indicates what kind of graph to create
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar()







# Changes the axis labels
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")







# Changes the color of the bar chart
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")







# Adds an orange outline
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")







# Changes the theme of the graph, making the background white
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue")  +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes") +
  theme_minimal()








Part a Reflect on the ggplot() code.
What’s the purpose of the +? When do we use it? - the + indicates that another function is being added to the ggplot function.
We added the bars using geom_bar()? Why “geom”? - It indicates that the graph is geometric
What does labs() stand for? - labs() stands for labels
What’s the difference between color and fill? - color changes the color of the border, fill changes the color of the entire bar.
Part b In general, bar charts allow us to examine the following properties of a categorical variable: observed categories: What categories did we observe? - difficulty
variability between categories: Are observations evenly spread out among the categories, or are some categories more common than others? - moderate is by far the most common category
We must then translate this information into the context of our analysis, here hikes in the Adirondacks. Summarize below what you learned from the bar chart, in context.
Part c Is there anything you don’t like about this barplot? For example: check out the x-axis again. - the x-axis is in alphabetical order not order of difficulty.
Exercise 6

ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_bar()








This is NOT an effective visualization because it creates a new bar for every unique elevation, making the bars small and difficult to read as very few peaks have the exact same elevation.
Exercise 8

ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.









Exercise 9

# Adds a histogram plot
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.








# Adds white border to bars in plot
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white") 

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.








# Makes the bars blue
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "blue") 

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.








# Adds axis labels
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white") +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.








# Changes the range of each bar to 1000
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 1000) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")







# Changes the range of each bar to 2
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 5) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")







# Changes the range of each bar to 200
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 200) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")








Exercise 11

ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_density(color = "blue", fill = "orange")








ggplot template:

#ggplot(___, aes(x = ___)) + 
  #geom___(color = "___", fill = "___") + 
  #labs(x = "___", y = "___")

PRACTICE

# Data on students in this class
survey <- read.csv("https://ajohns24.github.io/data/112/about_us_2024.csv")

# World Cup data
world_cup <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2022/2022-11-29/worldcups.csv")


ggplot(data=survey, aes(x = minutes_to_campus)) + 
  geom_histogram(color = "purple", fill = "navy")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.








ggplot(data=world_cup, aes(x=host)) +
  geom_bar(fill="green")
